physDesc.p: One page typewritten in black ink. Archival notes read "Aldington" in pencil at the top of the page. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I enclose a letter to Richard, which I have left open on purpose, so that you can read it before you send it on to him. It is, of course, to you both.

I am awfully sorry that you cannot do the London "chronique" while he is gone, but I perfectly understand why that would be impossible; and, as you will see by my letter to him, Braithwaite will keep the place open for him.

I know you are fearfully lonely, my Dear. I wish I were anywhere near, it would be so good if Ada and I could drop in on ou at intervals and cheer you up, and it would be so good for us to have you near by. But you are a brave woman, Hilda, and a good poet, and I believe those two qualities are the ones necessary to make a great artist. I have no words to describe my admiration for your poems. As I wrote Richard, they are exquisite and they are strong, and I think they will do a great deal to make people understand your work who did not quite get it in your smaller pieces, for no one can resist the human force, the tragic, awe-inspiring quality of these poems, even the people who know nothing of technique.

I am going to try to write to you and Richard very often while he is away. Shall I send his letters to you, or direct to him? I am sure you will see Fletcher before long, as it was one of his chief reasons for going to England.
